title: How can a black hole's own gravity, but not light, escape from it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Gravity does not prevent light from escaping. Light has no mass and is not subject to gravity. Light can be diffracted by matter around the sun. Black holes are not holes since they are argued to contain dense mass and should be called black bodies. These black bodies do not prevent light from escaping, simply because no light is observed here on earth from that space. Light can be simply extinguished, blocked, refracted, or pointed a different direction, etc. The last thing one should propose is that gravity is at fault. The original photographs of starlight during an eclipse in the 1902’s used a simple camera mount on the ground and did not control for the different atmospherics between morning and noon so the proposal that gravity bent starlight is mistaken. An actual astronomy telescope in England photographed the same episode and saw no bending at all. Indeed, light is not subject to gravity.

Because it turns out that General Relativty is a lot more mathematically sophisticated than pop science books and YouTube videos have led you to believe. The Einstein Field Equations of General Relativity relates the curvature of space-time, represented by the metric tensor, to the energy, mass and momentum in space-time, called the stress-energy tensor. The metric tensor in turn allows for the calculation of geodesics, or allowable paths through space-time. In a black hole, which is presumably what you are talking about, the allowable geodesics in space-time all lead towards the center of a black hole once anything is past the event horizon. That is, the only allowable paths through space and time through a black hole lead to the center, and none lead out of the black hole. If someone has told you it has to do with escape velocity, that person is basically telling you Santa delivers presents at Christmas.
